review.title: Boltzmann meets Nash: Energy-efficient routing in optical networks under uncertainty
review.abstract: Motivated by the massive deployment of power-hungry data centers for service provisioning, we examine the problem of routing in optical networks with the aim of minimizing traffic-driven power consumption. To tackle this issue, routing must take into account energy efficiency as well as capacity considerations; moreover, in rapidly-varying network environments, this must be accomplished in a real-time, distributed manner that remains robust in the presence of random disturbances and noise. In view of this, we derive a pricing scheme whose Nash equilibria coincide with the network's socially optimum states, and we propose a distributed learning method based on the Boltzmann distribution of statistical mechanics. Using tools from stochastic calculus, we show that the resulting Boltzmann routing scheme exhibits remarkable convergence properties under uncertainty: specifically, the long-term average of the network's power consumption converges within $\varepsilon$ of its minimum value in time which is at most $\tilde O(1/\varepsilon^2)$, irrespective of the fluctuations' magnitude; additionally, if the network admits a strict, non-mixing optimum state, the algorithm converges to it - again, no matter the noise level. Our analysis is supplemented by extensive numerical simulations which show that Boltzmann routing can lead to a significant decrease in power consumption over basic, shortest-path routing schemes in realistic network conditions.

metadata.title: Boltzmann Meets Nash: Energy-Efficient Routing in Optical Networks under Uncertainty

sections.text: Motivated by the massive use of power-hungry data centers to provide IT services, we are investigating the problem of optical network routing with the aim of minimizing traffic-related power consumption. To address this problem, we need to consider energy efficiency as well as capacity considerations; in addition, this needs to be done in fast-changing network environments in real time and distributed ways that remain robust in the event of random disturbances and noise. Considering this, we derive a pricing scheme whose Nash equilibrium matches the socially optimal states of the network, and we propose a distributed learning methodology based on the Boltzmann distribution of statistical mechanics. Using tools from stochastic calculation, we show that the resulting Boltzmann routing scheme exhibits remarkable convergence characteristics under uncertainty: in particular, the long-term average power consumption of the network converts within a period of maximum O-value (1 / 2), regardless of the size of the fluctuation.

metadata.abstractText: Motivated by the massive deployment of power-hungry data centers for IT service provisioning, we examine the problem of routing in optical networks with the aim of minimizing traffic-driven power consumption. To tackle this issue, routing must take into account energy efficiency as well as capacity considerations; moreover, in rapidly-varying network environments, this must be accomplished in a real-time, distributed manner that remains robust in the presence of random disturbances and noise. In view of this, we derive a pricing scheme whose Nash equilibria coincide with the network’s socially optimum states, and we propose a distributed learning method based on the Boltzmann distribution of statistical mechanics. Using tools from stochastic calculus, we show that the resulting Boltzmann routing scheme exhibits remarkable convergence properties under uncertainty: specifically, the long-term average of the network’s power consumption converges within ε of its minimum value in time which is at most Õ(1/ε2), irrespective of the fluctuations’ magnitude; additionally, if the network admits a strict, non-mixing optimum state, the algorithm converges to it – again, no matter the noise level. Our analysis is supplemented by extensive numerical simulations which show that Boltzmann routing can lead to a significant decrease in power consumption over basic, shortest-path routing schemes in realistic network conditions. Index Terms Boltzmann routing; energy efficiency; fluctuations; optical networks; uncertainty; Nash equilibrium.
